prompt: Write a poem about underpass echo in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem. Use a few invented coinages and a named creature. Avoid copying lines from the original.
poem:
The Whurlbeneath

’Tween twistytram and clattercave, where gloamlight dribbles down,
The whurlbeneath begins to brawl—a skrawling, scrapish sound;
It skitters through the iron ribs, it slithers round the beams,
Till every vowel and yammered yell unravels at the seams.

Beware the Grindlethroat, my child, that gulps the human cry!
It hoards the hollers, coughs them back, all smeared with diesel dye.
With grinnish gums and clangorclaws it loops the echoes tight,
Then drools them, warped and wavering, back into the night.

One eve I stepped beneath the span where shadow-shudders creep,
My footfall clacked like clapperclocks; the dark began to seep.
A swervish wind went whisper-whump, the lamps began to blink—
And sudden-sure the Grindlethroat uncoiled its iron drink.

It slurped my shout, it slapped it round, it twisted every tone,
Then belched it back in burbled shards that rattled brick and stone.
I fled through drumming thunderdrifts, through drizzles thick and brown,
Yet still the Grindlethroat pursued with mimic-glurping sound.

Now nightly when the traffic hums its hollow metal tune,
I hear my stolen syllables still wheeling round the dune.
So mark the underpass, dear heart, where echoes twist and float—
For somewhere in the girder-gloom still lurks the Grindlethroat.

poem:
The Brumabill Dawn  

Beware the brumabill, my child,  
the wobble-wake of dawn!  
The mistle-murk runs wild and wild,  
the snicker-sheen is gone.  
With goggy-gloves and glimmer-cloak,  
with whiffle-watch in hand,  
Go tiptoe where the dream-smoke broke  
across the sleep-soft land.  

The brumabill with wheezy wings  
will flump the dewy grass;  
Its shimmertooth for breakfast sings  
to every waking glass.  
But fling your flask of sunshiny,  
and whistle thrice for light;  
The fog will frizzle, frip and flee,  
and leave the day burn-bright.  

He took his glimmer-cloak in stride—  
so long the whiffling foe!—  
He danced through dim where shadows bide,  
and let the sunbeams grow.  
O frabjous morn! Callooh! Callay!  
The brumabill is gone;  
Come caper through the crystal day  
and sing the fog-song done!

**The Flimbertoggle's Déjà-Rewind**

and gumbrel skies went glimmerwing;  
through hitherthatch the zephyrs blew—  
when déjà-vu came déjà-new.

and spins each tick into a tock.”

a blade of twice-forgotten sand;  
he sought the echo-eater’s trail  
where yesterday had clipped its tail.

one glint of almost-maybe real—  
the Flimbertoggle looped, unlooped,

then folded into by-and-by.

with pocket full of timeworn husk;  
yet when he reached his candle-gate,

The Wubberwock of Music Room

The boomblatz in the timpani, the cymbals’ clanging clack!  
Take care the fluting flibberflute whose tootings twist and roam,

With baton braced and metronome, with tuners set just so,

For whoso braves the wubberwock returns a maestro rare!

The Cartoflummox

When foldsnarks flirpled through the ink;

The calibrant cut sharp its thread;  
The Grumbloque fell, its inkblood blue,

poem:
The Layover-Bay Ballad of Bristle-Blinker Brob

Beware the Layover Bay, my lad, where clock-hands twist and snurl,  
Its gates of gumdrop iron clang, its floors in furlongs whirl;  
The pipple-birds on perches perch, all spugged with spangle-spray,  
And timetables in taffeta flap the night to day.  

He took his portly portmanteau, his boarding pass of gold,  
A charger-fruit for dallying, a scarf against the cold;  
He packed a pouch of pepper-puffs and minted monorhyme—  
Then skipped through sliding silver doors, betwixt the chime of chime.  

Oh, hoot the huddled hush-hush hour when duty-free bells jingle,  
Where slumbrous slinkers snicker-snack and snack-bar pickles tingle;  
The gate, it yawned like yawp-whales wide, the carpet softly sighed,  
And LED constellations blinkered, neon-nurtured tide.  

Yet sudden! from the latte-mist rose Gribble-Grobb the Grue—  
With wheely-claw and charger flaw and eyes of cobalt blue;  
It guzzled gulps of gossip-news and burped a barcode song—  
Our traveler twirled his pepper-puffs and twanged his boarding gong!  

One, two! One, two! Through gate-queue blue, the pepper-puffs went pop!  
He danced the zigzag zither-step, he did the stop-and-hop;  
He swished his scarf in spiral-swirls, he rhymed the Grue away—  
It fizzled into fizzy mist beneath the Layover Bay.  

“Come clasp my cloak, thou clockwork folk! The Grue is gribbled dead!  
O frabjous flight, the upgrade’s right—recline thy weary head!”  
He texted home with trumpet-glee, he bought a keychain crown—  
Then soared beyond the snurling time, the Bay now upside-down.  

Beware the Layover Bay, my friends, yet fear not overmuch;  
Pack pepper-puffs and patience, let courage be your crutch;  
For every Grue that gloops the gate may vanish in a rhyme—  
He left it snoring neon dust, ahead of on-board chime.

The Monte-Carlo Jabberfrolly

Take heed, ye flibberant wanderlust—beware  
the bouncers at the blazen doors;  
tuck luck in pocket, polish your dare,  
for wheels that twinkle, clank, and roar.  
Polish your dare!  

Through gilded gloam where candelers flare,  
past fountains of fizzer and fern,  
the Monte-Carlo, shimmer-shock lair,  
tempts doubters to dance and to burn.  
Dance and to burn!  

Beware the flamblesliding deck  
where slickered high-rolls hiss—  
beware the croupiers’ quickside neck,  
and chips that vanish with a kiss.  
With a kiss!  

Come dressed in dapper glisterfray,  
with silver spats and cufflinky clink;  
carry a rabbit of yesterday,  
a whistle, and nerve made of ink;  
made of ink!  

Beware the baccarat bandersnake,  
the slot-o-whammer’s bling,  
the fling-fling-felt of velvet snake,  
the snap of fate’s swift spring.  
Swift spring!  

He twirled the chip—twice-tipped his hat,  
a hush of chandelieries hung;  
the red, the black, the spinnimat  
of stars like shuffled stropes were flung;  
were flung!  

O frabjous day! The flop fell fair,  
the roulette wheel gave back his dream—  
gold glug of coins in scented air,  
and jingle-coin fountains upstream;  
up the stream!  

Now gallop home, ye dazzled throng,  
with pockets plump with glee;  
sing flibber-songs all journey long—  
but leave one golden key.  
Golden key!

The Glimmergloam
